headline.main: MINNESOTA DOCTORS BEGIN EFFORT TO END SMOKING IN THE STATE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Medical Association has organized a coalition to end smoking in Minnesota by the year 2000. The association hopes to accomplish that goal mainly by educating the public on the hazards of smoking and proposing laws and public policies. ''We are not talking about prohibition of tobacco,'' Dr. A. Stuart Hanson, the prime mover behind the Minnesota Coalition for a Smoke-Free Society 2000, said Wednesday.

headline.main: HEART DISEASE DEATHS ARE DROPPING, BUT WHY?

docs.lead_paragraph: MIAMI IF the sharp drop in deaths from coronary disease over the past two decades is one of medicine's great successes - and a 37 percent decline would seem to qualify by anyone's reckoning - the reasons why have prompted one of medicine's major debates. Since 1968, cardiologists calculate, the lives of about 600,000 Americans have been spared. To some, the credit goes to leaner diets, fewer cigarettes, lower blood pressure and more exercise. Others point to leaps in medical care. Still others, however, are troubled by what the statistics don't explain. Although deaths are dropping, for example, it isn't clear whether the number of heart attacks is, too. And why is the heart disease death rate so much higher east of the Mississippi? As health care professionals by the thousands gathered here last week for the American Heart Association's annual convention, The Week in Review asked several prominent cardiologists for their views on the drop, its causes and the outlook for the future. Excerpts from their remarks follow: Pounds of Prevention
